name: Liron Gertsman
bio:
Professional Nature Photographer | Wildlife Biologist | Conservation Photojournalism | Vancouver, Canada |
Prints, tours, & workshops ⬇️

social_posts.post_text:
The Cygnus region of the night sky is filled with spectacular hydrogen-alpha emission nebulae, clouds of ionized gas glowing thousands of light years from Earth. However, due to their dim brightness and 656.28nm wavelength, they are invisible to the naked eye and require a modified camera and long exposures to reveal. I captured this image of Cygnus from the beautiful dark skies of Joshua Tree National Park, California!

It’s often said that photography is both an art and a science. In my opinion, the scientific side of photography is incredibly relevant for astrophotography, where knowledge of the night sky, photo gear, post-processing software, and meticulous planning are particularly important. This image integrates nearly 2.5 hours of exposure time over 34 images, stacked to reduce noise and increase detail (more technical info a comment below).

Shot using @gitzoinspires tripods #Gitzolnspires #FramedOnGitzo
Experiencing this winter wonderland in Northern British Columbia was definitely a highlight of 2022. I’m looking forward to more cold weather adventures in the new year!

A backlit Common Redpoll in flight against a dark backdrop of forest, photographed last winter in the Yukon. These beautiful finches have a nomadic lifestyle, meaning they are often found in different areas in different numbers each year based on food availability and reproductive success.

Tens of thousands of Bald Eagles reside around the Pacific coast of North America, but where they are found at different times of year is hugely influenced by food availability. Where food is abundant, spectacular gatherings of Bald Eagles will follow. My favourite Bald Eagle gathering takes place near Vancouver Island every summer. In this region, strong currents bring hake, a fish in the cod family, to the surface of the ocean. Hundreds of eagles will swoop down to capture them, making for a breathtaking sight and one of the best photo opportunities I’ve ever encountered. You can join me to photograph this spectacular phenomenon this July! More details can be found in the link on my bio.

10 to 20 thousand years ago, a star in the constellation Cygnus went supernova. Today, all that remains are clouds of ionized gas known as the Veil Nebula, expanding at around 415 kilometers per second (260 miles per second). While the explosion would have initially been bright enough to observe from Earth with the naked eye in the middle of the day, it now requires long exposures images and specialized photography gear to reveal in detail.⁠
⁠
I captured this image under the dark skies of southern California’s Joshua Tree National Park. By scouting the area during daylight hours, I was able to locate this tree, which was situated in the perfect direction to capture this image. The final result features a real alignment between the Veil Nebula and the Joshua Tree, integrating 28 minutes of stacked exposure time. The sky and the foreground were photographed from the same spot at a focal length of 275mm using a star tracker (for the sky exposures) mounted on an @gitzoinspires Systematic tripod.

There's currently a massive ball of ice flying past our planet: a comet known as C/2022 E3 (ZTF). On the night of January 28th, I took advantage of clear skies and headed away from Vancouver's city lights to photograph this celestial visitor! While the comet is currently visible high in the north all night, I set my alarm for 2:00am, and spent several hours in the early morning imaging. This was when the moon was below the horizon, making the skies darker and the comet more visible. It was a chilly -5°C (23°F) outside and even colder with a very strong wind chill, but seeing the turquoise glow of the comet show up on my camera screen brought a big smile to my face!⁠
⁠
Despite the fact that this comet is likely to be the brightest of 2023, it admittedly doesn't look like much to the naked eye. From a dark location, it appears as a faint star with a bit of a glow around it. A telescope or binoculars will reveal a bit more detail, but long exposure photographs are required to uncover the comet in all of its glory, including two tails: the ion tail (straight and blue-ish), and the dust tail (fan-shaped and warmer in colour). Also visible in this image is the bright turquoise atmosphere of the comet, known as the coma.⁠
⁠
This final image integrates about 70 minutes of stacked exposure time (75 second subframes), shot at 260mm using a star tracker on a @gitzoinspires tripod. Due to high winds shaking the trees as I was photographing the comet, I had to shoot a corresponding foreground of trees on a subsequent outing to complete this final image.⁠
⁠
No two comets are the same, and with a 50,033 year orbit around the sun, this one won't be visiting us in the inner solar system again anytime soon! Despite traveling past our planet at nearly 40 kilometers per second, its distance from Earth means it appears stationary to the eye. The comet reaches its peak brightness today (February 1st 2023), but is likely to remain visible for a bit longer, and photographable for some time!

Each spring, Ruddy Ducks gather on freshwater ponds and wetlands in the interior of my home province of British Columbia. In an attempt to land a mate, the males perform a spectacular and bizarre courtship display. The routine includes beating their beak against their breast feathers to create bubbles, and less-frequent rush forward through the water. Having observed the less-frequent rush part of the display several times over the years, I knew it had the potential for a particularly dramatic photo opportunity. With that shot in mind, I spent several days in my chest waders last spring at ponds where Ruddy Ducks were present. Standing still and concealed by the reeds, my patience was rewarded with a front-row seat to the courtship spectacle.

Few birds are as photogenic as Bald Eagles! I captured this one in flight lit by the sun, while the forest backdrop was in the shadows. By exposing for the highlights, I was able to get a black background effect for the image.⁠
⁠
I'm incredibly excited for my Bald Eagle photography workshops this July! Based out of beautiful Vancouver Island, we'll be photographing hundreds of eagles gathered to fish on hake, as well as other birds and wildlife that congregate in the region. The first week is now sold out, and there's limited spots remaining for week 2. If you'd like to join me, click the link in my bio or send me a message for more information!⁠

Black Bears on the British Columbia coast spend a lot of time foraging on the beach. With seemingly effortless strength they browse the intertidal zone, flipping over large rocks to consume marine organisms such as crabs that hide underneath. ⁠
⁠
On my Bald Eagle photography workshops this July, rather than having standardized departure times for excursions such as on ordinary group tours, our itinerary will be custom-tailored to have the best wildlife photography opportunities. When the current is strong, we’ll be with the Bald Eagles. When we have beautiful sunset light, you can be sure that we’ll be out seeking wildlife. When the tide is low, we’ll look for Black Bears such as this one foraging on the beach. Click the link in my bio to learn more!

A frequently elusive bird, the vast majority of Long-eared Owls I've seen have been tucked away deep in shrubbery, sleeping (as a nocturnal species, sleep during daylight hours is very important for these birds). Last month, I came across a Long-eared Owl at a unexpected location. Walking on a trail at dusk, I was surprised by an owl that suddenly flew past, emerging to hunt. Rapidly shifting my camera settings, I managed to capture a few flight shots at an ISO of 32000. It's remarkable how far camera low light performance and noise reduction software has come in recent years in order enable bright, detailed images in even the darkest conditions!

From bubble-netting Humpback Whales like these, to bears fishing for salmon, to large gatherings of birds, the Great Bear Rainforest offers an unparalleled wildlife viewing experience. I'm thrilled to be guiding in the region again in 2023, and you can join me on an expedition! By living aboard a sailboat for a week, you will be fully immersed in the Great Bear Rainforest ecosystem.⁠ Most of the Great Bear Rainforest is very remote, and difficult to access. However, staying on a live-aboard vessel solves that problem. You can expect to wake up in beautiful inlets and bays, where wildlife and spectacular natural beauty can be found without even needing to travel. Click the link in my bio or send me a message for more information!⁠
⁠
⁠As a professional photographer and wildlife guide, I've had the privilege of witnessing some incredible spectacles in the natural world, and have had the pleasure of sharing those experiences with other wildlife lovers. However, whales have undoubtedly brought out the most emotion I've ever seen in people. ⁠A critical feeding ground for Humpback Whales, Gitga’at and Kitasoo Xai'xais territory in the Great Bear Rainforest is one of the best places on Earth to see bubble-netting: a unique feeding behavior where groups of whales work together using bubbles and underwater coordination to corner schools of herring, and lunge to the surface to feed on them. We actually know surprising little about how the whales go about finding their food and coordinating underwater, but however they do it, it is an unforgettable experience to witness.⁠

Each year, salmon journey from the ocean back to the very streams that they were born, to give life to the next generation. Along the way, these remarkable fish provide a critical food source for a multitude of wildlife. For bears, the salmon are more than just a way to fill their stomachs; they can dictate reproduce success for the following season. Bears mate in the spring, but have delayed blastocyst implantation. So, cubs will only be born if there is sufficient food supply leading up to hibernation.⁠
⁠
The Great Bear Rainforest is one of the best places on earth to witness Grizzly Bears during the annual salmon run, and is the only place on earth catch a glimpse of the elusive Spirit Bear! I can't wait to return to the region for the 2023 season. For more info on joining me on a Great Bear Rainforest trip this fall, click the link in my bio!

I feel incredibly fortunate to live on the Fraser River Delta, a critical stopover site along the bird migration superhighway known as the Pacific Flyway. One of my favourite visitors to the Fraser River Delta are the Snow Geese, who migrate through by the hundreds of thousands and winter by the tens of thousands in the region. Despite attempts to encourage them to move elsewhere, they often land in the fields and marshes around the Vancouver International Airport. I photographed this scene at dusk, as the airport lights began to glow.

In my opinion, some of the most otherworldly looking birds are the frigatebirds. With their massive 7.5-foot wingspan and narrow wings, these pterodactyl-like birds have a particularly striking silhouette. As I watched this Magnificent Frigatebird effortlessly soaring across the sky at dusk, I noticed that it was heading directly for the moon.  Anticipating the moment, I was able capture this single image (not a composite)! The opportunity to combine bird photography with astrophotography is pretty rare, so I'm always on the lookout for scenarios where the two worlds collide.

This winter, I broke my personal record for most photos captured in the shortest period of time. Exploring a river estuary on the Pacific coast of Mexico, I encountered a large group of Black Vultures gathered to feast on a carcass that had washed up near the river mouth. I proceeded to capture 11,000 images of the spectacle in just a couple hours (and thousands more over the next few days)! While that may sound ridiculous, every fraction of a second is unique when photographing animals in action. So, capturing huge numbers of images can be important in order to get the best possible moment. Some of my favourite images were taken at sunset, when the birds began to depart for the evening and head off to roost. Positioning myself so the setting sun would be directly behind the birds as they took off, I was able to capture this shot!

The Great Bear Rainforest is world-renowned for its rich ecosystem and wildlife. However, the best known animal of the region is undoubtedly the Spirit Bear. With just a few hundred believed to be in existence, these white-coloured Black Bears are the result of rare genetic mutation. While guiding in the region this past fall, it was a dream come true to finally encounter this spectacular animal. As this Spirit Bear emerged from the forest and headed towards the mouth of a river, I took a photographic risk; rather than using a fast shutter speed and guaranteeing a sharp shot, I set my shutter speed to 1/40th of a second, hoping to get a more interesting result with some motion blur in the fast-moving water. I was rewarded with a couple images where the bear was sharp!⁠
⁠
You can join me on a Great Bear Rainforest expedition this fall! Click the link my bio for more information.

Sometimes, patience, combined with a bit of luck, pays off! The Great Gray Owl is one of the most sought-after birds by birders and photographers, and it's easy to see why. They are so spectacular in appearance, and are very fun birds to watch, using their remarkable hearing and silent flight to capture rodents hidden in the grass beneath the ground. This behaviour can present amazing photography opportunities, but it's important to give them enough space so that they can achieve success on their hunts. Exploring the countryside of the British Columbia interior, I spent some time last summer scanning along the edge of the forests and fields for this elusive predator. After spotting this owl and watching it for some time from a distance, it dove into the middle of a grassy field, and emerged with a rodent in its mouth. As I stared through my lens, it took flight, coming in my direction and landing on a fencepost just a short distance away. It devoured its prey as I watched and photographed in awe!⁠
⁠
This image was shot using a Canon EF 200-400mm f/4L IS USM Extender 1.4x Lens from @movrirentals.

Living on the Pacific Flyway near the Fraser River Delta, I'm fortunate to witness huge numbers of birds each year as they stop to rest and refuel along their migration route. For residents of this region, few feathered visitors gather as much attention as Snow Geese, who migrate through by the hundreds of thousands between their wintering grounds in North America, and their breeding grounds in Siberia. Wanting to capture what it was like to be in the middle of a flock of Snow Geese, I placed my camera in a grassy area where a few birds were starting to gather. Using wireless tethering, I sat some distance away, and controlled my camera remotely. It wasn’t long before several hundred more geese arrived, enabling me to capture this image! Despite being considered a nuisance by some, the geese provide a special connection to nature and delight many excited onlookers, such as the one visible in the bottom left corner of the frame.

You can join me to experience the magic of the Great Bear Rainforest this fall (link in bio)! As I get excited to return this incredibly wildlife-rich region, here’s a quick look back at some of the bears and whales encountered on last years’ trip.

When it comes to raising young, Red-necked Grebes put a high energy investment into supporting the survival of their chicks. Both parents will carry their young on their back, and delicately deliver a diverse array of aquatic invertebrates and small fish. Wanting to capture the intimate connection between parents and offspring, I spent a few days photographing on lakes in the interior of British Columbia, with several pairs of Red-necked Grebes. Due to regular human activity in the area, the birds seemed quite accustomed to human presence, and would go about their business undisturbed despite the occasional onlooker. As grebes slowly drifted by one morning, I captured this moment.

I'm thrilled to announce that my image of these two Rock Pigeons has been awarded the grand prize of the 2023 Audubon Photography Awards (@audubonsociety)!⁠
⁠
They may be common and non-native across most of the world, but I think that Rock Pigeons are amazing birds. They thrive in a huge variety of habitats, including where few other birds can: the city center. While I admittedly rarely point my lens at pigeons, I couldn’t resist watching and photographing this pair as they carefully groomed each other’s feathers, a behavior known as allopreening. They were perched in front of a dark backdrop: the underside of a pier. Purposefully exposing for the brighter parts of the image, the shadowy environment made for a studio-like black background behind these remarkable iridescent birds. It’s easy to overlook and underappreciate common species, so I hope this photo serves as a reminder to appreciate the beauty of even the most abundant birds. I hadn’t planned on photographing pigeons that day, but I’m glad that the beauty of this pair ultimately captured my attention.⁠
⁠
In addition to the grand prize, my image of a Northern Hawk Owl was awarded the honorable mention in the professional category. I'll share that shot here tomorrow, but in the meantime, I recommend checking out all the awarded images over at @audubonsociety!

In addition to the grand prize image I shared yesterday, I was also awarded the honorable mention in the professional category of the 2023 Audubon Photography Awards, for this image! An elusive and stunning bird, the Northern Hawk Owl is found across the boreal forest of my home country of Canada. This winter, I dedicated some time searching for these beautiful birds, and managed to locate 9 different individuals on their winter territories. Of all the hawk owls that I met, this bird and its mate were my favourites, but also the most physically challenging to photograph. The pair would roam throughout a territory of around 10 square kilometers, meaning I had to put in a lot of distance hiking in the freezing temperatures to find them. Despite wearing large snowshoes, I would regularly sink to my knees in the deep, powdery snow that blanketed the landscape. However, after putting on tens of miles on snowshoes, my efforts were rewarded with several unforgettable encounters with the pair of owls.  As they hunted and engaged in courtship throughout a large territory, I observed from a respectful distance in order to capture their natural behaviors. One morning, frost blanketing the trees made for a particularly stunning environment, and I captured this image as one of the owls perched at the tip of a tree.⁠
⁠
I'm thrilled to announce a brand new photography workshop! Taking place from February 19-25 2024, the workshop will focus on ethical photography of owls on the prairies and boreal forest of Canada. Great Gray Owls, Snowy Owls, Northern Hawk Owls and Great Horned Owls will be our primary targets, with a multitude of other species possible. Click the link in my bio or send me a DM for more information, or to register!
Meet the owls of Alberta! You can join me in February 2024 to experience them in person. Click the link in my bio or send me a DM for more information!

I can spend countless hours watching and photographing swallows, and those hours can certainly be necessary to try to capture these fast-flying birds in action! Here, a pair of Tree Swallows mate on the wood railing of a pier.⁠
⁠
Swallows accomplish impressive feats of migration, with some species migrating thousands of kilometers from Central or South America to their breeding grounds as far away as northern Canada or Alaska. The Tree Swallow, pictured here, is a cavity-nesting species. However, natural holes in trees are increasingly uncommon around urban areas, where dead trees are frequently removed. Due to habitat loss, insect declines (as a result of pesticides, habitat changes, and more), and climate change related pressures, aerial insectivores such as swallows are among the most rapidly declining bird groups on Earth. Fortunately, Tree Swallows have taken well to artificial nesting boxes, and as a result can still be seen nesting in urban parks and green spaces around my home city of Vancouver, and in other urban centers around North America. There's much work to do, but I hope we’ll be able to enjoy the spectacle of these aerial acrobats for generations to come.

FREE WEBINAR (more info below)! Growing up as a nature enthusiast, I became accustomed to seeing the Great Bear Rainforest and its inhabitants featured on magazine covers and in wildlife documentaries. It is no wonder the region is so well-known; the area is home to a rich abundance of coastal wildlife, including this emblematic creature found nowhere else on Earth: the Spirit Bear.⁠
⁠
Years later, I feel privileged to have had the chance to visit the spectacular region, and to get to share those experiences with fellow nature lovers. Join me this Friday (June 30) for a free webinar as I share some of my favourite stories and photographs from this spectacular ecosystem. Click the link in my bio to register!

Meet the ghost of the boreal forest: the Great Gray Owl. While they are experts at camouflage in the trees, their presence is often given away as they emerge at the forest edge to hunt. By observing them through binoculars or a telephoto lens, you really appreciate their spectacular, piercing yellow eyes!⁠
⁠
Great Gray Owls will be one of our target species on my 2024 Alberta Owls photography workshop, taking place February 19-25. This will be a small group, ethical owl photography experience in one of the best places on Earth to see these remarkable birds. Click the link in my bio or send me a message for more information!

One of the largest intact coastal rainforests in the world, the Great Bear Rainforest on British Columbia's coast is home to a spectacular array of wildlife. One of the highlights of a trip to the region are the estuaries, where salmon gather as they prepare to make their way up river to spawn. The abundance of food attracts a multitude of wildlife, including families of Grizzly Bears! Under the watchful eyes of their mother, this young cub and its sibling were playing amongst fallen trees washed up on the estuary shore. I captured this image as a cub stood up, holding on to a tree branch!⁠
⁠
I'll be sharing some of my favourite images and stories from the Great Bear Rainforest in a free live webinar this Friday, June 30 at 5:30pm pacific. Click the link in my bio to register!

With a highly unique aquatic lifestyle, the American Dipper has long been one of my favorite birds to watch and photograph. This winter, I spent some time seeking out dippers as they foraged in icy rivers and streams in the south interior of my home province of British Columbia. After a couple days of hiking around their habitat, I came across a particularly cooperative and active dipper foraging around the ice. Laying down in the snow, I spent five hours observing and photographing the scene, completely in awe of this aquatic songbird dipping into the freezing water. As the dipper emerged from a dive with a caddisfly larva, I captured this image! The protective cases of caddisfly larvae removed by the dipper can be seen on the snow, evidence of a productive feeding spot for this resilient bird.⁠
⁠
This image is featured in the "Top 100" of the 2023 @audubonsociety photography awards.

The Great Horned Owl is found across North and South America, but depending on where you see them, they vary quite a bit in plumage. My favourite Great Horned Owls are the "subarctic" subspecies, found across much of northern and central Canada. These birds sport a beautiful silvery plumage to compliment their snowy winter environment. Spotting this individual mid-day as it slept camouflaged against the trunk of a tree, I returned in the late evening and captured this image as the bird woke up and prepared to hunt.⁠
⁠
Great Horned Owls will be one of our target species during my 2024 small group ethical owl photography workshop, taking place in Alberta from February 19-25. Click the link in my bio for more information!

This past March, I spent a couple weeks chasing northern lights in Canada's north, and was treated to the most spectacular display of aurora that I've ever seen. ⁠
⁠
Although we had already had some success photographing the lights on previous nights, this particular outing started out slow. @ianharlandphoto and I set out around mid-day to Tombstone Territorial Park in central Yukon. After some daytime exploring to search for winter wildlife and locate some night photography compositions to return to, darkness fell, but the northern lights were nowhere to be seen.⁠
⁠
When I'm closer to urban areas, I can check live geomagnetic data from NOAA's DSCOVR spacecraft, which gives me a sense of what to expect from the aurora in the coming hour. That's a bit more challenging to do in Northern Canada, where populated centers are few and far between, and cell coverage is limited. Fortunately, I was in touch with my friend @imthehaker, who was relaying geomagnetic data to me via my satellite communication device. Around midnight, just as we were thinking of calling it a night, I got the message: "Data is looking good now. Around -5 to -7 Bz, hemispheric power rising to 45 and should be getting stronger". Sure enough, the sky suddenly exploded with light. From horizon to horizon, the sky was filled with mother nature's dance of fireworks. Green, purple and red were all visible to the naked eye, lighting up the snowy mountainscape. For a short period of time, the -40 degree temperature almost seemed to disappear as the dance of aurora mesmerized us.⁠ The spectacle continued into the early morning, and we were out until about 5:30am, making it the longest night of astrophotography I've experienced. I wouldn't have had it any other way!⁠
⁠
Here's one of many images from that night. Stay tuned for more aurora photos from the trip!

One of my favourite lighting conditions is when I have an animal illuminated by sunlight, against a backdrop in the shade. By exposing for the brighter parts of the image, this allows for a natural dark background effect!⁠
⁠
My 2023 Bald Eagle photography workshops have gotten off to a great start! We’ve witnessed hundreds of eagles fishing daily, as well as a multitude of other coastal wildlife. If you are thinking of joining a trip next year, sign up for the “wish list” to be notified when 2024 dates are released (visit the the link in my bio or send me a DM)!

Common Ravens are amazing birds. They are well known for their intelligence, but I also find them to be remarkably beautiful. I love to photograph them in the snow, when the bright surroundings act as a natural light reflector, bringing out subtle details and colours in their dark feathers. Ravens are one of the most common birds on the prairies of Canada in the winter, so I'm looking forward to seeing lots of them in the snow in 2024 during my Alberta Owls photography workshop, taking place February 19-25 (visit the ink in my bio for more information)!

Even though it may seem like summer has just begun in the northern hemisphere, many birds are already making their way south. Shorebirds like these Western Sandpipers are among the first of the southbound "fall" migrants! Here on the Fraser River Delta of British Columbia, the first individuals to show up tend to be adults that were not successful in raising young this year. They are followed by the rest of the adults, and then by the young of the year as they make their first migration later in the summer and into the fall. The majority of all Western Sandpipers in the world are believed to stop at the Fraser River Delta to refuel on their migration, and the numbers are particularly dramatic in spring, where during the peak of the migration it is normal to see tens or even hundreds of thousands of sandpipers at once.⁠
⁠
This photo of Western Sandpipers was captured at sunrise this past winter on the coast of Mexico, which is in the nonbreeding grounds of these birds. Having seen hundreds of thousands of Western Sandpipers migrating through my home region in British Columbia and thousands of individuals on the wintering grounds in Mexico, I always wonder what the chances are that I've seen the same individual twice, at different ends of the continent.

In an Instagram story last month, I asked you what your favourite owl species is. This was the winner: the Snowy Owl! Famous for their striking white plumage, bright yellow eyes, snowy choice of environment, and appearances in pop culture media such as Harry Potter, the Snowy Owl is a well known and loved species. The Canadian Prairies are one of the main wintering grounds for these birds, and they will be one of our main target species during my 2024 Alberta Owl photography workshop, taking place February 19-25. During the trip, we we will focus on photographing owls and learning how to find them, and using an ethical approach to capture their amazing natural behaviors. For more information or to book, visit the link in my bio, or send me a message!

Once the spring sun melts the ice on Canada’s interior lakes, Common Loons leave their coastal wintering grounds and begin to arrive inland. As summer arrives, pairs of Common Loons are hard at work on freshwater lakes, catching aquatic invertebrates and small fish to feed their young. Photographing this iconic bird required setting out at 4:00AM for several mornings, in order to find and photograph loon families in the sunrise light. I captured this moment as a loon parent emerged from a dive, carrying a fish in its beak for delivery to its chicks.⁠

Last night, the northern lights returned to the skies over my home city of Vancouver, Canada! I headed out to the north shore, and photographed the dance of the aurora over the the mountains, including the distinct double silhouette of the Twin Sisters (Ch'ich'iyúy Elxwíkn in the Squamish language, also known as “The Lions”). ⁠
⁠
This was probably the strongest aurora display I've witnessed over the Vancouver area, but it was also a quick one. The peak of the aurora activity occurred from around 10:45pm-11:15pm, after which the display began to weaken, and the colours began to fade with the light from the rising moon. ⁠
⁠
To the naked eye, the shape and and movement of the aurora was clearly visible, but the colours were not. However, while our eyes aren't very good at seeing colour in the dark, cameras are! Shooting at a large aperture of f/2, I was able to capture the full detail and colour of the aurora, and revealed further hidden details in post-processing.
Last night’s Northern lights, captured dancing over the north shore mountains near Vancouver, Canada!

It's hard to describe the feeling you get from being in the presence of a wolf. While I've only had a few encounters over the years, each one has left me in a state of awe.⁠
⁠
The coast of my home province British Columbia is home to an incredibly unique population of wolves, often known as coastal wolves, sea wolves, or rain wolves. Distinct from their inland counterparts, these canids spend less time hunting large prey, and more time foraging and scavenging in the intertidal zone. They are even known to fish for salmon during the annual spawning events!⁠
⁠
While they are frequently maligned for being predators, the important role of wolves in ecosystems as top-down regulators of the food web is well documented, most famously in Yellowstone National Park. There, reintroduction of wolves nearly 100 years after they had been hunted to local extinction led to restored natural predation on herbivorous species (such as elk), which led to improved vegetation growth, providing food and habitat to other species. This included increased food supply for beavers, who created new natural wetlands. Ultimately, the reintroduction of wolves in Yellowstone led to a remarkable increase in biodiversity. The natural regulation of herbivore populations by natural predators also has direct advantages to humans, reducing the prevalence of disease (which can spread to domestic animals), and reducing the risk of vehicle collisions with wildlife.⁠
⁠
Outside of protected areas, wolves in many regions remain heavily maligned and persecuted, due to a perceived threat to humans and our domesticated animals, as well as perceived threat to species that humans also like to hunt, such as deer and elk. While real conflict can occur between wolves and humans (and particularly our domestic animals), they can often be prevented through non-lethal mitigation measures and minor adjustments of our own behaviors and land use.⁠
⁠
(continued in the comments)

I photographed this Great Gray Owl as it landed at the tip of a tree on a bright overcast day in Alberta. Snowy winter conditions make for bright, even lighting that wonderfully shows off the feather details of these spectacular birds! While it is non-traditional in photography to have the subject facing away from the camera, I liked the simplistic look of this composition, bringing the focus to the subtle details of the flight feathers.⁠
⁠
My February 2024 "Owls of Alberta" photography workshop is now sold out! However, it's not too late to join the waitlist for 2024 (to be offered a spot in the event of a cancellation), or the wish list for 2025 (to be notified when 2025 dates are open for booking). Visit the link in my bio for more information!

Over many years of exploring remote natural places in western Canada, I've encountered many remarkable animals. However, I never would have imagined I would come to love Mountain Goats so much. They are so much better built for hiking than humans; I've found myself struggling to cross treacherous terrain, only to see a Mountain Goat traverse the same or even more difficult terrain with complete ease. This image was one of my favourites from a backcountry expedition several years ago!

There’s no feeling quite like being out under a dark, starry night sky, so far away from the city that the ground is being illuminated only by the light from space. The photons from the stars and galaxies that illuminate the ground have travelled hundreds, thousands, or even millions of light years to reach our eyes here on Earth. When the landscape is completely covered in snow, the ground reflects the light from space in a way that can sometimes make it difficult for the naked eye to discern where the sky ends and the ground begins. It makes you feel like you are suspended in a void, but it’s the most beautiful void imaginable. That was the feeling I had one night last March, when @ianharlandphoto and I were treated to a spectacular clear sky in -20C (-4F) temperatures in the far northwestern corner of British Columbia.⁠
⁠
Wanting to capture the vastness of the milky way stretching across the sky, I captured a 22-panel panorama with a 14mm lens, at f/2 to allow lots of light into the camera to reveal hidden details in the sky. Each panorama panel for the sky is a stack of two 1-minute exposures, a technique used to increase detail and reduce noise. The panels for the foreground are single 1-minute exposures. To give a sense of the scale of the landscape, I asked @ianharlandphoto to stand near the center of the composition, where he was aligned with the zodiacal light (a phenomena which causes the glow in the sky visible at the center of the image) shining over a rugged mountain peak. This is the final result!⁠

Meet the Bushtit: a tiny western North American songbird species that weighs in at 4-6 grams, which is about the same as our 25-cent coin. While they may not be colourful, their adorable flocks often draw attention as they bounce from one tree to the next with their tiny wings. Research in many parts of their range has found them to be cooperative breeders, with additional birds helping a pair attend to their nest and raise their young. These "helpers" (known as supernumeraries) are often adults (usually males) who failed to nest successfully that year, or sometimes offspring of the breeding pair from a previous brood that year.⁠
⁠
Bushtit nests are very large relative to their body size. The nests are sac-shaped, woven from spider web and plant materials. The seemingly immense effort required to build these nests is one theory as to why individuals who loose their nest or fail to raise young will often help out other nesting individuals that year, rather than re-build their own nest and start again. Sometimes, pairs that have failed to breed may even attempt to take over a nest built by another pair.⁠
⁠
As small and fast-moving birds, photographing Bushtits can be a bit tricky! This is one of my favourite shots I've captured of the species over the years. Once thing is for sure: there is much more going on in the lives of these little birds than meets the eye!

One of the most incredible things I've ever had the chance to experience in nature is the lek of the Sharp-tailed Grouse, a site where males gather to perform courtship displays for visiting females. Sharp-tailed Grouse typically arrive at their lek in darkness before sunrise, and will dance and display through much of the morning hours. These birds are notoriously flighty and sensitive to disturbance, so in order to observe them respectfully, I set up a hide outside the perimeter of the lek after dark. Waking up at 3 in the morning, I hiked for 45 minutes back through the dark to reach my hide. As the first sign of dawn light began to appear on the horizon, the displays began, with grouse dancing and producing otherworldly sounds on the lek. This Sharp-tailed Grouse belongs to the "Columbian" subspecies, a population that has disappeared from 90% of its former range across western North America, and is listed as a population of special concern in Canada and several US states.

While owls are often the focus of a winter wildlife photography trip to Canada’s prairies, the region is also a winter home to a multitude of other birds of prey. Falcons are a personal favourite, and the three species that are most regularly encountered in winter are the Gyrfalcon, Prairie Falcon, and Merlin. The Merlin is the smallest of the three, and the prairie subspecies is a striking pale grey and brown, quite different to the darker plumaged birds found closer to the coast. We’ll be keeping an eye out for photo opportunities with these and other bird species during my February 2024 Owls of Alberta photography workshop. The trip is now sold out, but you can still join the wait list for the trip or wish list for future trips at the link in my bio.

The Red Fox has evolved to survive in an impressive variety of habitats. In many areas, they are found deep in the woods. In some places, they are a frequent visitor to semi-urban backyards. In other places, they roam vast prairies. However, in the mountains of far northern British Columbia, the Red Fox has also conquered the harsh environment of the high alpine. Experiencing recorded temperatures from over 30 degrees Celsius (90 F) in the summer to nearly -50 degrees Celsius (-58 F) in the winter, this is an extreme environment. The foxes that reside here are true survivalists. ⁠ ⁠
⁠
I spotted this fox in the distance during the summer months, trotting along the side of a mountain road with a something in its mouth. As it walked past, I could see that it had snatched up a birds nest, likely belonging to some type of thrush, and was probably heading to a den hidden nearby to feed its pups. Using a relatively slow shutter speed, I tried to capture a sense of motion in the image.⁠ Watching the fox, I couldn't help but feel some wonder and amazement over this stunning animal and its ability to survive in a spectacular but incredibly harsh environment.⁠

Woodpeckers are such fascinating birds! I spent an hour watching and photographing this female Downy Woodpecker as she went from tree to tree, foraging for insects. Using her chisel-like beak, she chipped away at tree bark to get to to the bugs hiding underneath. Dead trees are often particularly favorable for woodpeckers, as the softer wood makes it easier for them to get to their prey of choice, and easier for them to excavate nest cavities. I was drawn to this particular composition by the dreamy look of the out of focus forest in the background.

The far north of British Columbia is a summer home to my favourite bird: the Arctic Tern. As I hiked into the higher elevations in an extremely remote mountain pass, what started out as a pleasant overcast day got colder and windier. Soon, it began to pour rain. As storm clouds swirled in the sky above, I finally arrived at my target destination: a beautiful alpine lake. Approaching the lakeshore, a tern flew over to investigate my presence in its territory, and I captured this image as it flew directly overhead in front of one of the most dramatic skies I’ve ever witnessed. Few birds are more at home in this harsh environment than the Arctic Tern, a species that can migrate nearly 100,000 kilometres (60,000 miles) every year despite weighing about the same as an iPhone. This world traveler nests as far north as the high Arctic, and spends the non-breeding season as far south as Antarctica!

The dance of Sharp-tailed Grouse on the lek is one of the most incredible things I’ve witnessed in nature. My 5-minute short film of the spectacle was just awarded the video award in the 2023 Bird Photographer of the Year competition! (@birdpoty)! You can watch the whole short video at the link in my bio.

I’ll be going live here on Instagram tomorrow (Thursday Sept 7) at 1pm pacific / 4pm eastern for a Q&A session, hosted by @audubonsociety. I hope to see you there!

Earlier this year, I set out to the interior of my home province of British Columbia, with the Bohemian Waxwing being one of my main photographic targets. I was thrilled to spend a few days watching and photographing these incredible birds as they foraged on plentiful winter berries. When people think of cold and temperate climates, they don’t often tend to think of spectacularly plumaged birds. However, many unbelievably beautiful avian species can be found here. Named in part for the red ends to their wing feathers, Bohemian Waxwings grow larger “waxy tips” as they get older. This individual was particularly strikingly adorned! Bohemian Waxwings can be found roaming through large regions throughout the year as they travel in search of large berry crops.

Bookings are officially open for my 2024 Bald Eagle and coastal wildlife photography workshop, taking place June 22-27 2024! Visit the link in my bio or send me a message for more information. Guiding the workshops this season near Vancouver Island was the highlight of my summer. Each day, we were treated to the spectacle of hundreds of Bald Eagles fishing for hake, as well as a multitude of other wildlife sightings. Getting to share these amazing experiences with photographers from around the world was incredibly special. I am beyond excited to do it again next year!⁠
⁠
This photo was captured this season under some of my favourite lighting conditions: soft evening backlight, against a backdrop in the shade. The backlight beautifully lights up the splash and edges of the wings, making the scene pop out against the shadows.

During my Bald Eagle and coastal wildlife photography workshops this past summer, we were treated on one evening to dozens of Humpback Whale breaches, where the animals leapt completely out of the water. The question was asked, “how are we going to top that tomorrow”? I didn’t know the answer, until we came across a few Humpback Whales the following evening, surfacing in perfectly calm and dark waters, with backlight from the setting sun spectacularly illuminating their breaths. It’s hard to explain in words, but the combination of the sight, sound, and serenity of the scene made for a truly special experience. After years of guiding people to see coastal wildlife here in British Columbia, I’ve found that few animals can bring a sense of magic and emotion to people like Humpback Whales do.

My 2024 Bald Eagle and coastal wildlife photography workshop will be taking place near Vancouver Island from June 22-27! Visit the link in my bio or send me a message for more information.

For a short window each summer, hundreds of Bald Eagles gather near Vancouver Island to fish for hake (a fish in the cod family) that get pushed to the surface by strong tidal currents. Watching hundreds of eagles swoop down to the water to fish is quite the sight to behold, and will be the focus of my June 22-27 Bald Eagle and coastal wildlife photography workshop! You often don’t know where to point your lens first; eagles fly down to capture hake non-stop, all-around you. You can have dozens, if not hundreds, of opportunities each hour to nail the perfect action shot. Combined with an incredible diversity of coastal wildlife, we’ll have ample opportunities to create a photography portfolio to be proud of.⁠ Visit the link in my bio or send me a message for more information, or to book!

The most spectacular aurora display I've witnessed to date was earlier this year, when the entire sky irrupted with dancing formations of green and magenta over the dark skies of central Yukon, in Canada's far north. The -40 degree temperature was no deterrent to what was an unforgettable night. Mesmerized by the northern lights, we went to bed at about 5:30am! ⁠
⁠
With nights getting longer in the northern hemisphere, aurora season is once again upon us. We had a great start to the season with a strong display last month, and I'm hoping for more opportunities soon! As we approach solar maximum (the period of greatest solar activity in the 11-year cycle), we'll hopefully be in for some nice geomagnetic activity this winter.

Each year, a combination of unique water movement and concentrated food availability attracts hundreds of eagles to a feeding frenzy near Vancouver Island. As strong tidal currents rapidly push huge volumes of water between islands, local upwelling occurs, creating "boils" that send fish, particularly hake, up to the surface. The eagles flying above often see the fish rising up through the water, and are ready to grab them the moment they reach the surface.⁠
⁠
I'm looking forward to experiencing this eagle gathering once again with my photography workshop guests next summer! Week 1 (June 22-27 2024) is now sold out, so we've opened up a second week: July 4-9 (and we are already down to limited spaces remaining). Visit the link in my bio or send me a message to learn more, or book your spot!

I spent Monday night camped out at nearly 2000 metres (6500 ft) elevation in the backcountry of the Cascade Mountains, located a couple hours drive east of my home city of Vancouver. With an Earth-facing filament eruption on the sun having occurred a few days prior, I was aware that some aurora activity would be possible. However, I did not anticipate that it would be the most impressive aurora show I’ve seen from southern British Columbia! It was overcast as it got dark, so I was not feeling too optimistic about the chances of seeing the Northern Lights. However, the clouds soon began to clear, revealing dancing pillars of light. Unlike every other aurora display I’ve seen from the Greater Vancouver region where the lights were restricted to the northern horizon, this one more resembled some displays I’ve seen in Canada’s far north, with the lights appearing in all directions. I captured this photo facing south, as a ghostly STEVE (Strong Thermal Emission Velocity Enhancement) and some green “picket-fence aurora” danced above the galactic core of our home galaxy, the Milky Way. After several hours, the spectacle began to quiet down and some new clouds began to roll in, so I settled into my sleeping bag in the below-freezing alpine temperatures. I woke up a few hours later to thick fog, strong winds, a layer of fresh snow on the ground, making for a unique and memorable night in the backcountry!

Wait for it… a Bald Eagle catches a hake that got pushed to the surface by strong tidal currents! This eagle fishing spectacle takes place each year near Vancouver Island, and is the focus of my 2024 Bald Eagle and coastal wildlife photography workshops. Weeks 1 and 2 are now sold out, but spaces remain for our newly announced week 3: July 21-26 2024. Click the link in my bio or send me a DM for more information!

Here's another image from last week, when a geomagnetic storm brought the northern lights to relatively southerly latitudes across the world, where they are rarely seen! I journeyed east of my home city of Vancouver into the Cascade Mountains, where I hiked into the backcountry for the night and camped at an elevation of nearly 2000 meters (6500 feet) in sub-freezing temperatures. Carrying a camera, several lenses, lighting, and a tripod up a mountain in addition to cold weather camping gear is also a good way to put your physical capabilities to the test. However, the feeling you get by being immersed in nature, far away from the city infrastructure, makes it so worth it. As a photographer, putting in that extra effort is also a good way to capture unique images!

As a professional photographer and wildlife guide, I've been fortunate to witness some amazing natural phenomena, and have gotten to share many memorable moments with wildlife lovers from around the world. However, I've found that few animals can bring out emotion in us humans like Humpback Whales do. So far, there is one animal in particular I've seen repeatedly move people to tears, and that's the Humpback Whale.⁠
⁠
During my 2023 Bald Eagle and coastal wildlife photography workshops near Vancouver Island, we were fortunate to spend time with Humpback Whales more or less every day, including some days with several dozen whales. One evening, we witnessed a double breach; immediately after one Humpback leaped out of the water, a second individual joined in! I captured this moment as the Humpback soared through the air in front of the sunset-illuminated splash of the first breaching whale.⁠
⁠
I'm looking forward to spending more time with these breathtaking giants once again next summer. Weeks 1 and 2 are now sold out, but there's still space to join me on our July 21-26 2024 photography workshop! Click the link in my bio or send me a message for more information.

Red Foxes are such impressive animals. In many places, they have to survive in harsh winter conditions where they use their highly sensitive hearing to precisely pinpoint and capture rodents buried deep beneath the snowy surface. As I photographed this fox in northwestern British Columbia, strong winds below over the landscape, adding additional chill to the already -15 degree C (5 F) temperatures. While I had ski goggles and a thick winter jacket to keep me warm, the fox simply squinted as it faced into the wind, with its fur on its side being parted by the gusts.

Late past this summer, I got to spend some time guiding on a sailboat in Haida Gwaii, a beautiful and unique collection of islands off the north coast of British Columbia. Late one afternoon, a relatively large pod of 9 Transient Orca made an appearance. Each orca can be identified to the individual by unique markings on their dorsal fin and saddle patch, and I identified this individual as T007B3 (Knox), a male born in 2005. Once fully grown, the dorsal fin on a male Transient Orca reaches 6 feet tall! Wanting to showcase the already impressive height of T007B3’s sprouting dorsal fin, I knew I needed to photograph from the lowest angle possible. Holding my camera just a few inches above the waves, I captured this shot.

I've recently a couple weeks immersed in the coastal ecosystems of British Columbia, documenting the annual return of salmon to our rivers. The importance of salmon to a multitude of wildlife species, including Black Bears, is always apparent. For many bears, salmon are critical resource to help put on sufficient weight for winter. The quality and quantity of food they consume also dictates bear reproductive success. Mating occurs in spring and early summer, but blastocyst implantation is delayed until the fall, and will only occur if the female bear has consumed sufficient resources. So, the reproductive success of bear populations can be closely linked to the availability of food sources like salmon. ⁠
⁠
Wanting to capture the relationship between the bears and salmon in a somewhat unique photo, I recently spent a few days dedicated to trying to get one specific image: a split over/underwater shot, with both a bear and salmon visible. Pulling off the shot required finding a spot that had a high concentration of salmon, such that there would almost always be fish swimming by. That spot also had to be by a bear trail or fishing area, so I spent time observing the river area in order to figure out areas of high bear traffic. To get a clear division between the above water and underwater parts of the image, it also had to be a place with calm water flow. After finding a suitable spot, I had to overcome the technical challenges of securing an underwater camera system in place so that you could clearly see above and below the water at the same time, and setting it up to trigger remotely. I ended up setting the camera to trigger on an interval, so it would automatically take a photo every two seconds. ⁠
⁠
After three days spent with my camera in the river, I managed to capture this photo of a Black Bear above, and a bright female Pink Salmon below. There is still much room for improvement, but I was satisfied with what I was able to learn over a few days, which will hopefully allow me to have greater success with future attempts!⁠
⁠
Shot on a @canoncanada R5 with a 14mm lens in an @aquatech_imagingsolutions underwater housing, on an @gitzoinspires Mountaineer tripod.

A Bald Eagle hones in on its target…

Each year, hundreds of eagles gather to fish for hake in strong tidal currents near Vancouver island, making for one of the most spectacular sights I’ve ever seen, and the best Bald Eagle photography opportunity I’ve ever encountered. You can join me to experience the spectacle in person during my July 21-26 2024 wildlife photography workshop (weeks 1 and 2 are sold out)! Visit the link in my bio or send me a message for more information!

Yesterday (October 14th) an annular solar took place, visible to some extent across most of North and South America. With solar eclipses being such rare occurrences, I had been thinking about how I was going to photograph it since the start of the year, and had decided I wanted to try to take a more unique approach by incorporating birds into my images. Fast forward to this week, and I began to closely follow the weather forecast, to determine where I’d need to be in order to escape the clouds. Unfortunately, much of the Pacific Northwest would be blanketed by overcast skies. As the forecast updated each day, I went through a few plan revisions, but ultimately made the call the day before the eclipse to travel to Victoria at the south end of Vancouver Island, where gaps in the clouds were forecasted for a couple hours during the eclipse. I was actually hoping for some thin passing clouds, which would soften the light and make for a more striking scene. My planning was rewarded with wonderful conditions for eclipse viewing, and I spent the ~2 hour duration of the partial eclipse trying to line up birds with the sun. Here are some of the results! Let me know which of these 5 images is your favourite. Bonus points if you can identify the birds from their silhouettes!

I had the pleasure to guide once again this year in the spectacular Great Bear Rainforest, on British Columbia’s north and central coast. It was an unforgettable experience spent with spectacular wildlife and wonderful guests from around the world! I’m so excited to be returning once again to the region next year, and my August 28 - September 4 2024 trip is now open for booking. Click the link in my bio or send me a message for more information!⁠
⁠
One of the highlights of being a wildlife guide and visiting the same places year after year, is that you get to know and recognize individual animals. This is a female Grizzly Bear that I first met with her yearling cubs in 2022, and was thrilled to see once again with the same cubs in 2023. One morning, she watched from the top of the riverbank (image 1), as her two cubs successful caught a chum salmon below (image 2). Hopefully we'll encounter her again next season!

While in the Great Bear Rainforest this year, we woke up on a couple mornings to the sound of howling wolves! While it may be possible to go unnoticed in the field by some wildlife species, it is near impossible to do so with wolves; encounters with these animals only take place on their terms. So, it was an incredibly special experience to witness this wolf pack socializing in front of us. While I don’t ever go in with the expectation of seeing wolves, I’m looking forward to searching for them again next year! You can join me in the Great Bear Rainforest in 2024 from August 28 to September 4th (visit the link in my bio or send me a message for more information).

Pacific salmon are incredible. They are born in freshwater rivers, journey to the sea where they live and grow for most of their lives, and then they somehow manage to return to the exact rivers where they were born several years later to reproduce, giving life to the next generation. It’s an effort that takes a harsh toll on their bodies, making the return to freshwater streams a one-way trip for most salmon populations. While I’ve always been amazed by salmon since learning about them, spending time underwater with them to see their strength and perseverance up close makes me all the more in awe.

Here’s a series that’s a bit different from my usual posts! Wanting to capture salmon underwater from a unique perspective, I did some freediving this fall, and secured my camera in an underwater housing at the bottom of a 10 meter (33 foot) river canyon. Leaving it there, I set it to take one photo every second on an interval. This way, I was able to capture the fleeting moments when salmon would pass by, from the unique perspective of being directly below them (first image). The third image is an unintentional selfie captured as I went to retrieve the camera! The second image was taken with camera in hand as I dove down to the bottom of the canyon, and captured a single salmon swimming by with @krossphotos silhouetted at the surface. Let me know which of the three compositions you prefer!

Last winter, I dedicated quite a bit of time to looking for Northern Hawk Owls in western Canada. Throughout my searches, I managed to find 9 individuals on their winter territories, but this individual and its mate were both my favourite individuals to photograph, and the most physically challenging. The birds roamed a territory of around 10 square kilometers, so I had to put on many miles each day on snowshoes in freezing temperatures in order to keep up with their movements through the deep and powdery snow. I captured this shot as one individual came in for a landing at the tip of a frost-covered tree. I'm hoping for more encounters with these gorgeous birds this winter!

A Bald Eagle feeding frenzy! I can’t wait to experience this again next summer, and you can join me! Two trips are already sold out, but there’s still space to join me on week 3 of my Bald Eagle and coastal wildlife photography workshops, taking place on July 21-26 2024. The focus of the trip is witnessing and photographing hundreds of eagles gathered to fish for hake, but we also spend time with the abundance of other coastal wildlife species found near Vancouver Island. Visit the link in my bio or send me a message for more information!

Only a few hundred Spirit Bears are believed to exist, and they are all located in the Great Bear Rainforest and adjacent areas around British Columbia's north and central coast. These spectacular animals are Black Bears with two copies of a mutant MC1R gene, which makes their fur white. The recessive trait is found in 10-20% of Black Bears in the area. Research suggests their white fur may provide better camouflage than black fur from the perspective of their salmon prey, who would often look up at them with the bright sky behind. ⁠
⁠
I photographed this beautiful individual as it emerged from the cover of the forest and into the light on the exposed shoreline! I'm looking forward to searching for these and other amazing animals of the Great Bear Rainforest again next year, and you can join me! Click the link in my bio or send me a message for more information on my August 28 - September 4 2024 Great Bear Rainforest trip.

When I spotted this Yellow Warbler foraging along the top of a fence, I managed to line it up with the sunset in the background, catching it's silhouette in front of the evening sky! While photographing, just a a tiny step or two in any direction can completely change what's the in the background (or foreground) of your image, especially when shooting with a telephoto lens.

There’s nothing quite like the sight of a Humpback Whale launching itself into the air! During my Great Bear Rainforest tour this year, we watched in awe as this individual and its calf each breach about 30 times consecutively. Here’s a slow-motion clip of one of those breaches!

The annual salmon run on the British Columbia coast brings one of my favourite spectacles in nature: huge gatherings of Bald Eagles! Tens of thousands of them are drawn to to the region each year, where they scavenge on the carcasses of spawned-out salmon. When one eagle finds a nice salmon carcass, others will often fly in, hoping for a piece. A photography outing during heavy rain was rewarded when these three eagles flew in to where other eagles had already gathered, spreading their wings simultaneously.

Every night, thousands of crows from around Greater Vancouver gather on one street to roost. Their commute across the city parallels the daily commute of people heading home from work. This daily journey is the subject of a 4-minute CBC short I co-filmed and co-produced with @_jack.bailey._ and @budsaurus. Click the link in my bio to watch it!
